physDesc.p: There are also a number of other emendations and additions by the Tremulous Hand of Worcester.

handNote.p: Ker's scribe 'O'. The scribe Wulfgeat. A round Anglo-Saxon miniscule. A slight lean to the right. Round, unroofed a; a mixture of descending insular long s and tall s; round d with short ascender that usually has a small flick or curve to the upper-right at its tip. Ash is of oe-form, with o always somewhat smaller, sometimes with tall e. e is horned, with a short tongue and a squinting eye. Ascenders of tall letters are wedged, leaning towards forking; thorn is noticeably forked. a is quite rounded in form. This is the same hand as that identified by ECHOE handID DP1032.

An addending hand generally using a somewhat more finely-cut pen. The hand is marked by its tendency to leave a small gap at the top of e and fondness for an upwardly-curling long tongue on e. This hand sometimes adds interlinear Latin glosses or 'vel'-alternatives in other homilies. The same hand can be seen in other places in Hatton 113 and Hatton 114, generally inserting words either by extending the descender of a letter downward to mark the intended insertion area, or using a double-punctus marking. This is the same hand as that identified by ECHOE handID EC1032a.
